subject: Politics
title: What Is Disinformation
description: A 1-minute de-risking session on What Is Disinformation.

hook.text: Russia spent $1.25 million per month on fake social media accounts to influence the 2016 US election. It worked.

buildup.text: Disinformation is false info spread to deceive on purpose. Misinformation is false but shared without that intent.

discovery.text: State-sponsored disinformation campaigns target elections, public health, and social cohesion across many countries.

twist.text: Disinformation works not by convincing everyone but by creating confusion. When nobody trusts anything, lies win.

climax.text: Detecting disinformation requires media literacy. But education systems haven't adapted to the digital age.

punchline.text: Disinformation doesn't need believers. Confusion is the weapon itself.

quiz.question: What is the difference between disinformation and misinformation?
options: Disinformation is deliberately false; misinformation is false but shared without intent to deceive
There is no difference between the two terms
Misinformation is always more harmful than disinformation
